cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
"Which American legal TV drama-comedy (2004 to 2008), a spin-off of ""The Practice"", followed the exploits of attorneys at Crane, Poole & Schmidt?"
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
1. The question specifies a legal TV drama-comedy that aired between 2004 and 2008.
2. It mentions that this show is a spin-off of "The Practice," which is a well-known legal drama.
3. The show in question follows the exploits of attorneys at a fictional law firm named Crane, Poole & Schmidt.
4. Given these clues, I recall that the show "Boston Legal" fits all these criteria. It aired from 2004 to 2008, is a spin-off of "The Practice," and centers around the attorneys at the mentioned law firm.

Answer:
Boston Legal

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
"Which American legal TV drama-comedy (2004 to 2008), a spin-off of ""The Practice"", followed the exploits of attorneys at Crane, Poole & Schmidt?"
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['BULLET::::- Crane, Poole & Schmidt, a fictional law firm in the television series "Boston Legal"\n', 'The Practice is an American legal drama created by David E. Kelley centering on the partners and associates at a Boston law firm. Running for eight seasons on ABC from March 4, 1997, to May 16, 2004, the show won the Emmy in 1998 and 1999 for Best Drama Series, and spawned the spin-off series "Boston Legal", which ran for five more seasons, from 2004 to 2008.\n', '"The Practice" is an American legal drama created by David E. Kelley centring on the partners and associates at a Boston law firm. The series was broadcast for eight seasons from 1997 to 2004, initially as a mid-season replacement. "The Practice" won many Primetime Emmy Awards, including Outstanding Drama Series in 1998 and 1999. As part of the fictional universe in which many shows produced by David E. Kelley are set "The Practice" had crossover story arcs with "Gideon\'s Crossing", "Boston Public", and "Ally McBeal" in addition to its own more jovial spin-off series "Boston Legal", which was broadcast from 2004 to 2008.\n', 'A spin-off of the long-running Kelley series "The Practice", "Boston Legal" follows the exploits of former "Practice" character Alan Shore at the legal firm of Crane, Poole & Schmidt where he is best friends with founding partner Denny Crane and is arguably their best lawyer.\n', '"Boston Legal" on ABC, premiering in 2004, gave continuity and success to the Kelley franchise. It was a spin-off of his long-running legal drama "The Practice", and followed attorney Alan Shore (a character who became the star of "The Practice" in its final season, played by James Spader) to his new law firm, Crane, Poole & Schmidt. It also starred veteran television actors Candice Bergen and William Shatner. Critically popular with less than spectacular ratings (ranked 27th for the first season, 46th for the second), the show was an "Emmy darling" during its run, winning seven times and being nominated over 25 times. The show won the Peabody Award in 2005 for its signature political commentaries.\n', 'BULLET::::- Crane, Poole & Schmidt, a fictional Massachusetts law firm\n', 'Crane, Poole & Schmidt is shown to be a very large and respected law firm with offices across the United States as well as international locations. It is said there are some 50 senior partners besides the named ones, several of which have appeared on the show.\n', 'Boston Legal is an American legal dramedy that ran on ABC from October 3, 2004, to December 8, 2008. The show follows the cases and personal lives of the lawyers of law firm Crane, Pool and Schmidt. The show has been nominated for a variety of awards, including 26 Primetime Emmy Awards, eleven Screen Actors Guild Awards, six Satellite Awards, four Golden Globe Awards, two Producers Guild of America Awards and a Peabody Award.\n', '"Boston Legal" is a spin-off of long-running Kelley series "The Practice", following the exploits of former "Practice" character Alan Shore (James Spader) at the legal firm of "Crane, Poole & Schmidt". During the course of the series, 101 episodes of Boston Legal aired over five seasons.\n', '"The Firm" marks the third television adaptation of a John Grisham novel. "The Client" was a 1995 adaptation of the 1993 novel of the same name that aired 21 episodes on CBS between September 17, 1995, and April 16, 1996, during the 1995–96 United States television season. Grisham was not credited for the development of that adaptation. "The Street Lawyer" was a 2003 adaptation of the 1998 novel of the same name that never aired on ABC that was developed for the 2003–04 United States television season. "Ford County" (2009) is also in development at NBC.\n']

### Foundational Knowledge:
1. **Show Title and Duration**: "Boston Legal" is the title of the show, which ran from October 3, 2004, to December 8, 2008.
2. **Spin-off Origin**: It is a spin-off of the earlier legal drama "The Practice," which aired from 1997 to 2004.
3. **Setting**: The show is set in a fictional law firm named Crane, Poole & Schmidt.
4. **Main Characters**: The series follows attorney Alan Shore, portrayed by James Spader, who is a character that originated in "The Practice." Denny Crane, played by William Shatner, is another central character and a founding partner of the firm.
5. **Genre**: "Boston Legal" is classified as a legal dramedy, combining elements of drama and comedy.

### Advanced Information:
1. **Crossover and Continuity**: The show maintains continuity with "The Practice," featuring character arcs and relationships that were developed in the original series. This connection enhances the narrative depth and character development in "Boston Legal."
2. **Critical Reception**: The show was critically acclaimed, winning seven Emmy Awards and receiving numerous nominations, indicating its quality and popularity despite mixed ratings.
3. **Cultural Commentary**: "Boston Legal" is noted for its political commentaries, which contributed to its recognition, including a Peabody Award in 2005.
4. **Character Dynamics**: The relationship between Alan Shore and Denny Crane is central to the show, highlighting themes of friendship, loyalty, and moral ambiguity in the legal profession.

### Role of the Content:
The extracted information serves to deepen the understanding of the question by providing context about the show's origins, its narrative structure, and its cultural significance. This foundational and advanced knowledge equips the model with a richer understanding of the show, enabling a more nuanced response to questions about it and its place in American television history.

Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence.

question_info.question: "Which American legal TV drama-comedy (2004 to 2008), a spin-off of ""The Practice"", followed the exploits of attorneys at Crane, Poole & Schmidt?"
passages:
BULLET::::- Crane, Poole & Schmidt, a fictional law firm in the television series "Boston Legal"
The Practice is an American legal drama created by David E. Kelley centering on the partners and associates at a Boston law firm. Running for eight seasons on ABC from March 4, 1997, to May 16, 2004, the show won the Emmy in 1998 and 1999 for Best Drama Series, and spawned the spin-off series "Boston Legal", which ran for five more seasons, from 2004 to 2008.
"The Practice" is an American legal drama created by David E. Kelley centring on the partners and associates at a Boston law firm. The series was broadcast for eight seasons from 1997 to 2004, initially as a mid-season replacement. "The Practice" won many Primetime Emmy Awards, including Outstanding Drama Series in 1998 and 1999. As part of the fictional universe in which many shows produced by David E. Kelley are set "The Practice" had crossover story arcs with "Gideon's Crossing", "Boston Public", and "Ally McBeal" in addition to its own more jovial spin-off series "Boston Legal", which was broadcast from 2004 to 2008.
A spin-off of the long-running Kelley series "The Practice", "Boston Legal" follows the exploits of former "Practice" character Alan Shore at the legal firm of Crane, Poole & Schmidt where he is best friends with founding partner Denny Crane and is arguably their best lawyer.
"Boston Legal" on ABC, premiering in 2004, gave continuity and success to the Kelley franchise. It was a spin-off of his long-running legal drama "The Practice", and followed attorney Alan Shore (a character who became the star of "The Practice" in its final season, played by James Spader) to his new law firm, Crane, Poole & Schmidt. It also starred veteran television actors Candice Bergen and William Shatner. Critically popular with less than spectacular ratings (ranked 27th for the first season, 46th for the second), the show was an "Emmy darling" during its run, winning seven times and being nominated over 25 times. The show won the Peabody Award in 2005 for its signature political commentaries.
BULLET::::- Crane, Poole & Schmidt, a fictional Massachusetts law firm
Crane, Poole & Schmidt is shown to be a very large and respected law firm with offices across the United States as well as international locations. It is said there are some 50 senior partners besides the named ones, several of which have appeared on the show.
Boston Legal is an American legal dramedy that ran on ABC from October 3, 2004, to December 8, 2008. The show follows the cases and personal lives of the lawyers of law firm Crane, Pool and Schmidt. The show has been nominated for a variety of awards, including 26 Primetime Emmy Awards, eleven Screen Actors Guild Awards, six Satellite Awards, four Golden Globe Awards, two Producers Guild of America Awards and a Peabody Award.
"Boston Legal" is a spin-off of long-running Kelley series "The Practice", following the exploits of former "Practice" character Alan Shore (James Spader) at the legal firm of "Crane, Poole & Schmidt". During the course of the series, 101 episodes of Boston Legal aired over five seasons.
"The Firm" marks the third television adaptation of a John Grisham novel. "The Client" was a 1995 adaptation of the 1993 novel of the same name that aired 21 episodes on CBS between September 17, 1995, and April 16, 1996, during the 1995–96 United States television season. Grisham was not credited for the development of that adaptation. "The Street Lawyer" was a 2003 adaptation of the 1998 novel of the same name that never aired on ABC that was developed for the 2003–04 United States television season. "Ford County" (2009) is also in development at NBC.
